fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to A) \to A, satisfying: \begin {align*} \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a) &= a\\ \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p)) \end {align*}

This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities.
  296lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha  : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to  A) \to  A, satisfying:
       \begin {align*}       \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . a) &= a\\       \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ  \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda  p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))      \end {align*}   
  298lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \oplus _s with arity n \cong  P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations:
       \begin {align*}       \oplus _\iota \ (\oplus _s\ \vec {t}) &= \oplus _s\ \vec {t}\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _\iota \ t_1)\ \dots \ (\oplus _\iota \ t_n) &= \oplus _s\ t_1\ \dots \ t_n\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _{f(1)}\ \vec {t_1})\ \dots \ (\oplus _{f(n)}\ \vec {t_n}) &= \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)}\ \vec {t_1}\ \dots \ \vec {t_n}     \end {align*}   
  I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \oplus _\iota  is not necessarily unary in that case, and \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)} may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \oplus _{f(i)} - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.
